title: 108_s820
content: The Act titled "Perchlorate Community Right-to-Know Act of 2003" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include a section on Perchlorate Pollution Prevention. The Perchlorate Pollution Prevention Fund is defined as the Fund established by subsection (i)(1). A perchlorate storage facility is a facility that stores more than 375 pounds of perchlorate in a calendar year, excluding facilities storing perchlorate for retail or law enforcement purposes. Any person causing a discharge of perchlorate into waters must notify authorities. Any person causing a discharge of perchlorate into US waters must promptly notify the Administrator and State water pollution control agency, including details of the discharge volume and extent, and relevant monitoring documents. Any person causing a discharge of perchlorate into US waters must promptly notify the Administrator and State water pollution control agency, including discharge details and monitoring documents. Failure to provide notice may result in misdemeanor charges and fines ranging from $500 to $5,000. This requirement also applies to discharges under permits issued under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. Owners or operators of perchlorate storage facilities must submit a report to the Administrator and State water pollution control agency by January 1, 2005, detailing perchlorate storage volumes, storage methods, and monitoring documents dating back to January 1, 1950. Penalties collected will be deposited in the Fund. The Administrator must publish a list of perchlorate storage facilities and discharges annually, in consultation with State water pollution control agencies. The civil penalties for violations at perchlorate storage facilities range from $500 to $5,000 per day, with the amount determined by factors such as harm caused, nature of violation, duration, and past violations. The Administrator shall promulgate regulations by June 1, 2005, requiring perchlorate storage facilities to meet industry training standards and best management practices. An outreach effort will educate facility owners and operators on these regulations. Penalties collected will be deposited in the Fund. The Administrator, in coordination with State water pollution control agencies, will implement a loan program to help public water suppliers and private well owners obtain clean water to replace perchlorate-contaminated water. Applicants must submit an application for a loan of $10,000 to $750,000, with the loan term specified. The loan term can be up to 20 years if secured by real property or up to 10 years if not. The interest rate is tied to Federal securities with a 10-year term. Loan funds can cover 100% of costs for acquiring clean water. The Administrator may charge a loan fee. The Administrator may charge a loan fee of up to 2 percent of the loan amount to an applicant. The fee collected will be deposited in the Perchlorate Pollution Prevention Fund, which consists of various deposits and interest earned on investments. The Perchlorate Pollution Prevention Fund allows the Administrator to request transfers for necessary expenses and loans. Up to 5 percent of the Fund can be used for administrative expenses. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing the Fund amounts. The Secretary of the Treasury invests the Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States, either on original issue or by purchasing outstanding obligations at market price. Any acquired obligation can be sold at market price. The Secretary of the Treasury invests the Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States, either on original issue or by purchasing outstanding obligations at market price. The interest and proceeds from the sale or redemption of these obligations are credited to the Fund. Transfers of amounts to the Fund are made monthly from the general fund of the Treasury based on estimates by the Secretary of the Treasury, with adjustments for any discrepancies. Reports are required to be submitted within one year of enactment. The Administrator must submit annual progress reports to specific Senate and House committees regarding the implementation of the section. State laws are not preempted by this section, including those with more stringent requirements.
